HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, JANUARY IS, 1965

Segregation Dying, Says King
"Segregation is on Its deathbed today, but the civil rights
movement still has a long way
to go," declared the Rev. Martin
Luther King in his address to
over 1400 in Shriver Hall, Monday.
Segregation may be on its
deathbed, but "the main problem in the future is how costly
the segregationists will make the
funeral," he said.

Dr. Martin Luther King

Council Considers Proposal on Gent's Code
(Continued from Page 1)
The idea of a group of collegiate
men behaving themselves without exterrnal intervention would
be attractive to some people.
To actively support the Honor
System the Council proposes to
Utilize the powers given it in the
Constitution by establishing an
investigatory mechanism to deal
With non-academic Honor System violations.
The investigation of the alleged Gentleman's Code violations will be conducted by a
standing committee of three
Permanent members.
It will cooperate with a defense counsel, any member of
the Student Council clian by
the accused to represent the defendant's interest, in compiling
and assessing evidence.
The committee will make a
report reviewing evidence and
recommending penalty at a
Council meeting. The Council
Will then accept or reject the
committee's report and advise
the Deans as to action taken

with the parties involved.
The honor committee proposal
will be decided upon at the next
Council meeting in February.
Students interested or concerned
in this action should make their
views known to a Council member.

Genflemen and the Council
Several months ago the Student Council appointed
a committee to consider methods by which the Council
might best exercise its power to enforce the Gentlemen's
Code. The Council now has before it a suggestion by
that committee that a three-man board be set up to
investigate alleged violations of the code.
In investigating alleged violations, the board, composed of one sophomore, one junior, and one senior
Student Council representative, would also decide to its
own satisfaction the guilt or innocence of the accused.

CAREERS IN STEEL

Our representative will be on campus

FEBRUARY 16 and 17
to interview candidates for Bethlehem's 1965
Loop Course training program.
THE LOOP COURSE trains selected college graduates with management potential for
careers with Bethlehem Steel. The Course begins
in early July and consists of three phases:
(1)five weeks of orientation at our headquarters
in Bethlehem, Pa.; (2) specialized training in
the activity or field for which the Looper was
selected; and (3) on-the-job training which prepares him for more important responsibilities.
OPPORTUNITIES are available for men interested in steel plant operations, sales, research,
mining, accounting, finance, and other activities.
DEGREES required are mechanical, metallurgical, electrical, chemical, industrial, civil,
mining, and other engineering specialties; also
chemistry, physics, mathematics, business administration, and liberal arts.
If you expect to be graduated before July, 1965,
and would like to discuss your career interests
with a Bethlehem representative, see your
placement officer to arrange for an interview
appointment—and be sure to pick up a copy of
our booklet "Careers with Bethlehem Steel and
the Loop Course." Further information can be
obtained by writing to our Manager of Personnel, Bethlehem, Pa,

"Segregation is on Its deathbed today, but the civil rights
movement still has a long way
to go," declared the Rev. Martin
Luther King in his address to
over 1400 in Shriver Hall, Monday.
Segregation may be on its
deathbed, but "the main problem in the future is how costly
the segregationists will make the
funeral," he said.

The idea of a group of collegiate
men behaving themselves without exterrnal intervention would
be attractive to some people.
To actively support the Honor
System the Council proposes to
Utilize the powers given it in the
Constitution by establishing an
investigatory mechanism to deal
With non-academic Honor System violations.
The investigation of the alleged Gentleman's Code violations will be conducted by a
standing committee of three
Permanent members.
It will cooperate with a defense counsel, any member of
the Student Council clian by
the accused to represent the defendant's interest, in compiling
and assessing evidence.
The committee will make a
report reviewing evidence and
recommending penalty at a
Council meeting. The Council
Will then accept or reject the
committee's report and advise
the Deans as to action taken

with the parties involved.
The honor committee proposal
will be decided upon at the next
Council meeting in February.
Students interested or concerned
in this action should make their
views known to a Council member.

CAREERS IN STEEL

Our representative will be on campus

FEBRUARY 16 and 17
to interview candidates for Bethlehem's 1965
Loop Course training program.
THE LOOP COURSE trains selected college graduates with management potential for
careers with Bethlehem Steel. The Course begins
in early July and consists of three phases:
(1)five weeks of orientation at our headquarters
in Bethlehem, Pa.; (2) specialized training in
the activity or field for which the Looper was
selected; and (3) on-the-job training which prepares him for more important responsibilities.
OPPORTUNITIES are available for men interested in steel plant operations, sales, research,
mining, accounting, finance, and other activities.
DEGREES required are mechanical, metallurgical, electrical, chemical, industrial, civil,
mining, and other engineering specialties; also
chemistry, physics, mathematics, business administration, and liberal arts.
If you expect to be graduated before July, 1965,
and would like to discuss your career interests
with a Bethlehem representative, see your
placement officer to arrange for an interview
appointment—and be sure to pick up a copy of
our booklet "Careers with Bethlehem Steel and
the Loop Course." Further information can be
obtained by writing to our Manager of Personnel, Bethlehem, Pa,
